Cinnamon-Oat Peach Crisp Recipe | Bon Appétit




Skip to main contentOpen Navigation MenuMenuStory SavedTo revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories.Close AlertCloseStory SavedTo revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved storiesClose AlertCloseSign InSearchRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastMerch ShoprecipesJune 2018 IssueCinnamon-Oat Peach CrispBy Bryan FurmanMay 22, 20184.6(22)Read ReviewsTriangleEmailPinterestPrintPhoto by Peden + Munk, food styling by Sue Li, prop styling by Rebecca BartosheskyEmailPinterestPrintEmailPinterestPrintThis dead-simple oat topping can be repurposed for any stone fruit as it comes into season this summer or for pears and apples in fall. This recipe is from B’s Cracklin’ BBQ in Savannah, GA. Read more about pitmaster Bryan Furman here.Ingredients8 servings5lb. medium peaches (about 12), peeled, sliced ½" thick⅔cup granulated sugar2Tbsp. plus 1 cup all-purpose flour2cups old-fashioned oats⅔cup (packed) light brown sugar4tsp. ground cinnamon1tsp. kosher salt1cup (2 sticks) chilled unsalted butter, cut into small pieces2pints vanilla ice creamPreparationStep 1Toss peaches, granulated sugar, and 2 Tbsp. flour in a large bowl to combine. Let sit, tossing occasionally, 30 minutes.Step 2Meanwhile, whisk oats, brown sugar, cinnamon, salt, and remaining 1 cup flour in a large bowl to combine. Using an electric mixer on low speed, gradually add butter. Once it has all been added, increase speed to medium-high and beat until dry ingredients are incorporated (there should be no dry bits left in the bowl), about 3 minutes.Step 3Place a rack in center of oven; preheat to 350°. Scrape peaches and any juices into a 13x9" baking dish. Evenly scatter oat topping over peaches and bake crisp until peaches are soft, fruit juices are bubbling, and topping is a deep golden brown, 60–70 minutes. Transfer baking dish to a wire rack and let crisp cool 1 hour.Step 4Divide among bowls and top with large scoops of ice cream.How would you rate Cinnamon-Oat Peach Crisp?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (10)Back to TopTriangleUse oat flour (rolled oats blitzed in the Vitamiz) to sub for AP flour and it works great gluten free!Joanna9/15/2021Has anyone tried this with frozen fruit? Everyone went in for a second and third serving, perfectly balanced and timing to keep texture of peaches.AnonymousItaly7/9/2018This is delicious. For people giving it less stars because there’s no cook time...hello! It’s says 350! Try it. Love it. gaskinsej4909SC7/7/2018Topping is great. Mixed dry ingrdients in food processor and then pulsed in butter cubes. Perfect consistency. Will use again for other fruit crisps.tmarabGeorgia6/17/2018A bit of an editing fail to omit the oven temp. I baked it at 375F and also buttered the pan, though I didn't see any instructions there either. Swapped in nectarines and it was delicious! It is worth noting that the crumble is pretty dark going into the oven, making it difficult to tell when it hits the deep golden brown point.
